p: E. cardamomum oil is known for its characteristic aroma and is widely used in the food and cosmetic industries as a flavoring and fragrance agent. It is an intestinal smooth muscle relaxant [ 11] and has exhibited antispasmodic, antidiarrheal, and antibacterial activities [ 12, 13]. The antibacterial effect of essential oil of E. cardamomum against several Gram-negative bacteria [ 14] such as Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas aeruginosa has been reported. E. coli commonly resides in human colon and frequently causes diarrhea [ 15], whereas P. aeruginosa also causes diarrhea, and it may effect immune-deficient or antibiotic-treated individuals, which is difficult to treat due to its innate resistance to several antibiotics [ 16, 17, 18]. P. aeruginosa transmitted through the food chain may cause gastrointestinal infections [ 19]. Hence, both of these organisms directly or indirectly are potentially involved in the etiology of diarrhea.
